Description: Shoulder sherd of perhaps Aeolian pottery neck-amphora; exterior: painted decoration consisting of four black rows of scales with dot in added white at centre of each scale.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Cook states that although the scales are typical of Clazomenian black-figure pottery, they are not exclusive to Clazomenian pottery and therefore, the origin of this specific sherd cannot be confirmed although Clazomenian scales tend to be long (Cook 1952, 143, n. 102, no. 7). Modern inscription written in ink 'NAU 17' on break (accession number used in clay analysis). According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 80, NAU17), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Aeolis.
Bibliographic references: Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (p. 78, p. 80, p. 82-3, fig. 1) (NAU 17)
Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 143, n. 102, note 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.043) (Phase 1)
